instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02016: What is 820-02016? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - Cycling
threads.message:
Hello,

I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is stuck at 5v and cycling. My amp meter reads 5v with 0.1 amp before the amps drop to zero and my meter turns off completely before turning back on, repeating what I mentioned. The only history I have of the machine is that it stopped working after the trackpad was hit. The machine is otherwise in clean condition, there is zero liquid damage. The machine is also not able to enter dfu mode. 

<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> - 3.8v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> -12.26v
<SIGNAL>PPVDD_SOC_S1</SIGNAL> - 0.663v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S2</SIGNAL> - 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_AWAKE_NAND</SIGNAL> - 2.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_S2</SIGNAL> - 1.2v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2_UPC</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S2</SIGNAL> - 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC0_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC1_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC0_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC1_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - 1.5v

Here are some measurements I am able to check before it cycles off. 

Any help would be appreciated. Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - Cycling
threads.message:
All USB-C ports have the same behavior?

Looks like machine tries to boot and overcurrent is detected and gets blocked.
Disconnect all, and test the board alone; only USB-C charger connected.
Also try SMC bypass.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - Cycling
threads.message:
Yes, same thing for both ports.

I tried both your suggestions but it's the same issue. It still boot loops.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - Cycling
threads.message:
Probably broken traces, or solders.
Check for short, or pulsing voltage on big coils and other power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - Cycling
threads.message:
Hello!

New to this forum, but have almost same symptoms on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board, was wondering if you found the issue.
This one does 5V 200mA for a short time, then goes down to ~40mA before shutting down and starting the cycle anew.
Measured the mentioned points aswell:

<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> - ~3.8v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> -12.3V then 12.0V and going down during reset
<SIGNAL>PPVDD_SOC_S1</SIGNAL> - ~0.67v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S2</SIGNAL> - ~1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_AWAKE_NAND</SIGNAL> - 2.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_S2</SIGNAL> - 1.22v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2_UPC</SIGNAL> - 3.28v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S2</SIGNAL> - 5.2V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC0_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.25v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC1_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.25v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC0_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - ~1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC1_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - ~1.5v 
They are almost all pretty much the same as yours.
I found this rewa video and was wondering if it was this issue?

The voltage and amp reading are kinda off, due to them using some weird 20V -> USB-C adapterbrick.

[MEDIA=youtube]7qTlLmiK20M[/MEDIA]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power - Cycling
threads.message: PLEASE, open new thread with your problem...
